Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer erred in rejecting the applicants' protection claim under subsection 112(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: No new evidence presented to rebut RPD credibility findings or address inconsistencies
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate risk of persecution with new evidence
Credibility_Factor: RPD previously found credibility issues; PRRA officer found no change
Legal_Rule: PRRA is not an appeal of RPD decisions and does not reconsider previously available evidence
Procedural_Issue: PRRA conducted based on written submissions without oral hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by in-laws, mistreatment of Biharis in Bangladesh
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of new credible evidence
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: PRRA process followed legal standards; no procedural unfairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Written submissions, prior RPD decision, credibility concerns
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 112(1), section 167 of the Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Alleged errors in PRRA assessment process
Court_Result: Decision upheld; no basis to substitute PRRA officer's findings
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 112(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Defendant_Response: PRRA officer maintained denial based on credibility and lack of new evidence
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (PRRA officer), Federal Court (review)
Claimant_Status: Principal applicant and family seeking protected person status
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Risk of persecution, family conflict, ethnic minority status
Governing_Rule: Section 167 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
